The main function treated in this chapter is the Riemann zeta function \zeta\left(s\right).

The main related functions are the Hurwitz zeta function \zeta\left(s,a\right) , the dilogarithm \mathrm{Li}_{2}\left(z\right) , the polylogarithm \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right) (also known as Jonquière’s function \phi\left(z,s\right) ), Lerch’s transcendent \Phi\left(z,s,a\right) , and the Dirichlet L -functions L\left(s,\chi\right).
Elsewhere \zeta\left(s\right) is defined by analytic continuation.
It is a meromorphic function whose only singularity in \mathbb{C} is a simple pole at s=1 , with residue 1.
For further expansions of functions similar to (LABEL:eq:ZE.EX.ZE1) (Dirichlet series) see §LABEL:sec:NT.EP.
For B_{2k} see §LABEL:sec:BP.DE.BNP, and for \widetilde{B}_{n}\left(x\right) see §LABEL:sec:BP.DE.PBEF.
\zeta\left(s\right)=\prod_{p}(1-p^{-s})^{-1}, subject to \Re s>1, product over all primes p.

\zeta\left(s\right)=\frac{(2\pi)^{s}e^{-s-(\gamma s/2)}}{2(s-1)\Gamma\left( \tfrac{1}{2}s+1\right)}\prod_{\rho}\left(1-\frac{s}{\rho}\right)e^{s/\rho}, product over zeros \rho of \zeta with \Re\rho>0 (see §LABEL:sec:ZE.ZERO.DIST); \gamma is Euler’s constant (§LABEL:sec:GA.Def.EC).

para.sentence: Equivalently, \xi\left(s\right)=\xi\left(1-s\right), where \xi\left(s\right) is Riemann’s \xi -function, defined by: \xi\left(s\right)=\tfrac{1}{2}s(s-1)\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}s\right)\pi^{-s/2} \zeta\left(s\right).
For similar representations involving other theta functions see ( , p. 339) .
In (LABEL:eq:ZE.INT.ADV2)–(LABEL:eq:ZE.INT.ADV6), 0<\Re s<1 , \psi\left(x\right) is the digamma function, and \gamma is Euler’s constant (§LABEL:sec:GA.Def).
(LABEL:eq:ZE.INT.ADV3) is also valid for 0<\Re s<2 , s\neq 1.

\zeta\left(s\right)=\frac{1}{s-1}+\frac{\sin\left(\pi s\right)}{\pi}\*\int_{0} ^{\infty}(\ln\left(1+x\right)-\psi\left(1+x\right))x^{-s}\mathrm{d}x, \zeta\left(s\right)=\frac{1}{s-1}+\frac{\sin\left(\pi s\right)}{\pi(s-1)}\* \int_{0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{1}{1+x}-\psi'\left(1+x\right)\right)x^{1-s} \mathrm{d}x, , \zeta\left(1+s\right)=\frac{\sin\left(\pi s\right)}{\pi}\int_{0}^{\infty}\left (\gamma+\psi\left(1+x\right)\right)x^{-s-1}\mathrm{d}x, \zeta\left(1+s\right)=\frac{\sin\left(\pi s\right)}{\pi s}\int_{0}^{\infty} \psi'\left(1+x\right)x^{-s}\mathrm{d}x, , \zeta\left(m+s\right)=(-1)^{m-1}\frac{\Gamma\left(s\right)\sin\left(\pi s \right)}{\pi\Gamma\left(m+s\right)}\*\int_{0}^{\infty}{\psi^{(m)}}\left(1+x \right)x^{-s}\mathrm{d}x, subject to m=1,2,3,\dots.

\zeta\left(s\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(1-s\right)}{2\pi i}\int_{-\infty}^{(0+)} \frac{z^{s-1}}{e^{-z}-1}\mathrm{d}z, subject to s\neq 1,2,\dots, where the integration contour is a loop around the negative real axis; it starts at -\infty , encircles the origin once in the positive direction withoutenclosing any of the points z=\pm 2\pi\mathrm{i} , \pm 4\pi\mathrm{i} , …, and returns to -\infty.
The contour here is any loop that encircles the origin in the positive direction not enclosing any of the points \pm\pi\mathrm{i} , \pm 3\pi\mathrm{i} , ….

With c defined by (LABEL:eq:ZE.FE.Cdef) and n=1,2,3,\dots , (-1)^{k}{\zeta^{(k)}}\left(-2n\right)=\frac{2(-1)^{n}}{(2\pi)^{2n+1}}\sum_{m=0 }^{k}\sum_{r=0}^{m}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{k}{m}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{m}{r} \Im(c^{k-m})\*{\Gamma^{(r)}}\left(2n+1\right){\zeta^{(m-r)}}\left(2n+1\right), , (-1)^{k}{\zeta^{(k)}}\left(1-2n\right)=\frac{2(-1)^{n}}{(2\pi)^{2n}}\sum_{m=0} ^{k}\sum_{r=0}^{m}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{k}{m}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{}{m}{r} \Re(c^{k-m})\*{\Gamma^{(r)}}\left(2n\right){\zeta^{(m-r)}}\left(2n\right), , \zeta'\left(2n\right)=\frac{(-1)^{n+1}(2\pi)^{2n}}{2(2n)!}\left(2n\zeta'\left( 1-2n\right)-(\psi\left(2n\right)-\ln\left(2\pi\right))B_{2n}\right).
For definite integrals of the Riemann zeta function see ( , §2.4) , ( , §3.2) , and ( , §3.2) .
For other sums see ( , pp. 648–649) , ( , pp. 355–357) , ( ) , and ( , Chapter 3) .

If x\geq 1 , y\geq 1 , 2\pi xy=t , and 0\leq\sigma\leq 1 , then as t\to\infty with \sigma fixed, \zeta\left(\sigma+it\right)=\sum_{1\leq n\leq x}\frac{1}{n^{s}}+\chi(s)\sum_{1 \leq n\leq y}\frac{1}{n^{1-s}}+O\left(x^{-\sigma}\right)+O\left(y^{\sigma-1}t^ {\frac{1}{2}-\sigma}\right), where s=\sigma+it and \chi(s)=\pi^{s-\frac{1}{2}}\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}-\tfrac{1}{2}s\right)/ \Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{2}s\right).

If \sigma=\frac{1}{2} , x=y=\sqrt{t/(2\pi)} , and m=\left\lfloor x\right\rfloor , then(LABEL:eq:ZE.APP.APP1) becomes \zeta\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+it\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{m}\frac{1}{n^{\frac{1}{2}+it}}+ \chi\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+it\right)\sum_{n=1}^{m}\frac{1}{n^{\frac{1}{2}-it}}+O \left(t^{-1/4}\right).
For other asymptotic approximations see ( ) , ( ) ; see also ( , pp. 380–389) .
The product representation (LABEL:eq:ZE.EX.PR1) implies \zeta\left(s\right)\neq 0 for \Re s>1.
Also, \zeta\left(s\right)\neq 0 for \Re s=1 , a property first established in ( ) and ( ) in the proof of the prime number theorem (LABEL:eq:ZE.PRIM.PRIM3).
The functional equation (LABEL:eq:ZE.FE.FE1) implies \zeta\left(-2n\right)=0 for n=1,2,3,\dots.
Except for the trivial zeros, \zeta\left(s\right)\neq 0 for \Re s\leq 0.
In the region 0<\Re s<1 , called thecritical strip, \zeta\left(s\right) has infinitely many zeros, distributed symmetrically about the real axis and about the critical line \Re s=\frac{1}{2}.
The Riemann hypothesis states that all nontrivial zeros lie on this line.

Calculations relating to the zeros on the critical line make use of the real-valued function Z(t)=\exp\left(i\vartheta(t)\right)\zeta\left(\tfrac{1}{2}+it\right), where \vartheta(t)=\operatorname{ph}\Gamma\left(\tfrac{1}{4}+\tfrac{1}{2}it\right)- \tfrac{1}{2}t\ln\pi is chosen to make Z(t) real, and \operatorname{ph}\Gamma\left(\frac{1}{4}+\frac{1}{2}it\right) assumes its principal value.
Because |Z(t)|=|\zeta\left(\frac{1}{2}+it\right)| , Z(t) vanishes at the zeros of \zeta\left(\frac{1}{2}+it\right) , which can be separated by observing sign changes of Z(t).
Because Z(t) changes sign infinitely often, \zeta\left(\frac{1}{2}+it\right) has infinitely many zeros with t real.
Riemann developed a method for counting the total number N(T) of zeros of \zeta\left(s\right) in that portion of the critical strip with 0<t<T.
By comparing N(T) with the number of sign changes of Z(t) we can decide whether \zeta\left(s\right) has any zeros off the line in this region.

Sign changes of Z(t) are determined by multiplying (LABEL:eq:ZE.APP.APP3) by \exp\left(i\vartheta(t)\right) to obtain theRiemann–Siegel formula: Z(t)=2\sum_{n=1}^{m}\frac{\cos\left(\vartheta(t)-t\ln n\right)}{n^{1/2}}+R(t), where R(t)=O\left(t^{-1/4}\right) as t\to\infty.

The error term R(t) can be expressed as an asymptotic series that begins R(t)=(-1)^{m-1}\left(\frac{2\pi}{t}\right)^{1/4}\frac{\cos\left(t-(2m+1)\sqrt{ 2\pi t}-\frac{1}{8}\pi\right)}{\cos\left(\sqrt{2\pi t}\right)}+O\left(t^{-3/4} \right).
Riemann also developed a technique for determining further terms.
Calculations based on the Riemann–Siegel formula reveal that the first ten billion zeros of \zeta\left(s\right) in the critical strip are on the critical line ( ( ) ).
More than one-third of all the zeros in the critical strip lie on the critical line ( ( ) ).
For further information on the Riemann–Siegel expansion see ( ) .
The function \zeta\left(s,a\right) was introduced in ( ) and defined by the series expansion \zeta\left(s,a\right)=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{1}{(n+a)^{s}}, subject to \Re s>1, a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots.
\zeta\left(s,a\right) has a meromorphic continuation in the s -plane, its only singularity in \mathbb{C} being a simple pole at s=1 with residue 1.
As a function of a , with s ( \neq 1 ) fixed, \zeta\left(s,a\right) is analytic in the half-plane \Re a>0.
The Riemann zeta function is a special case: \zeta\left(s,1\right)=\zeta\left(s\right).

For most purposes it suffices to restrict 0<\Re a\leq 1 because of the following straightforward consequences of (LABEL:eq:ZE.HZE.RX1): \zeta\left(s,a\right)=\zeta\left(s,a+1\right)+a^{-s}, \zeta\left(s,a\right)=\zeta\left(s,a+m\right)+\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}\frac{1}{(n+a)^{ s}}, subject to m=1,2,3,\dots.
Most references treat real a with 0<a\leq 1.

In (LABEL:eq:ZE.HZE.DER2)–(LABEL:eq:ZE.HZE.DER8) primes on \zeta denote derivatives with respect to s.

\zeta'\left(s,a\right)=-\frac{\ln a}{a^{s}}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{a}{s-1} \right)-\frac{a^{1-s}}{(s-1)^{2}}+\frac{s(s+1)}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{( \widetilde{B}_{2}\left(x\right)-B_{2})\ln\left(x+a\right)}{(x+a)^{s+2}}\mathrm {d}x-\frac{(2s+1)}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\widetilde{B}_{2}\left(x\right)-B_ {2}}{(x+a)^{s+2}}\mathrm{d}x, subject to \Re s>-1, s\neq 1, a>0.

(-1)^{k}{\zeta^{(k)}}\left(s,a\right)=\frac{(\ln a)^{k}}{a^{s}}\left(\frac{1}{ 2}+\frac{a}{s-1}\right)+k!a^{1-s}\sum_{r=0}^{k-1}\frac{(\ln a)^{r}}{r!(s-1)^{k -r+1}}-\frac{s(s+1)}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{(\widetilde{B}_{2}\left(x\right) -B_{2})(\ln\left(x+a\right))^{k}}{(x+a)^{s+2}}\mathrm{d}x+\frac{k(2s+1)}{2} \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{(\widetilde{B}_{2}\left(x\right)-B_{2})(\ln\left(x+a \right))^{k-1}}{(x+a)^{s+2}}\mathrm{d}x-\frac{k(k-1)}{2}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac {(\widetilde{B}_{2}\left(x\right)-B_{2})(\ln\left(x+a\right))^{k-2}}{(x+a)^{s+ 2}}\mathrm{d}x, subject to \Re s>-1, s\neq 1, a>0.

\zeta'\left(1-2n,\frac{h}{k}\right)=\frac{(\psi\left(2n\right)-\ln\left(2\pi k \right))B_{2n}\left(h/k\right)}{2n}-\frac{(\psi\left(2n\right)-\ln\left(2\pi \right))B_{2n}}{2nk^{2n}}+\frac{(-1)^{n+1}\pi}{(2\pi k)^{2n}}\sum_{r=1}^{k-1} \sin\left(\frac{2\pi rh}{k}\right){\psi^{(2n-1)}}\left(\frac{r}{k}\right)+ \frac{(-1)^{n+1}2\cdot(2n-1)!}{(2\pi k)^{2n}}\sum_{r=1}^{k-1}\cos\left(\frac{2 \pi rh}{k}\right)\zeta'\left(2n,\frac{r}{k}\right)+\frac{\zeta'\left(1-2n \right)}{k^{2n}}, where h,k are integers with 1\leq h\leq k and n=1,2,3,\dots.

\zeta\left(s,a\right)=\frac{1}{2}a^{-s}+\frac{a^{1-s}}{s-1}+2\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{\sin\left(s\operatorname{arctan}\left(x/a\right)\right)}{(a^{2}+x^{2})^{ s/2}(e^{2\pi x}-1)}\mathrm{d}x, subject to s\neq 1, \Re a>0.

\zeta\left(s,a\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(1-s\right)}{2\pi i}\int_{-\infty}^{(0+ )}\frac{e^{az}z^{s-1}}{1-e^{z}}\mathrm{d}z, subject to s\neq 1, \Re a>0, where the integration contour is a loop around the negative real axis as described for (LABEL:eq:ZE.INT.CI1).

\int_{0}^{a}x^{n}\psi\left(x\right)\mathrm{d}x=(-1)^{n-1}\zeta'\left(-n\right) +(-1)^{n}h(n)\frac{B_{n+1}}{n+1}-\sum_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^{k}\genfrac{(}{)}{0.0pt}{} {n}{k}h(k)\frac{B_{k+1}(a)}{k+1}a^{n-k}+\sum_{k=0}^{n}(-1)^{k}\genfrac{(}{)}{0 .0pt}{}{n}{k}\zeta'\left(-k,a\right)a^{n-k}, subject to n=1,2,\dots, \Re a>0, where h(n)=\sum_{k=1}^{n}k^{-1}.

\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\frac{(-1)^{n}}{(n+a)^{s}}=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(s\right)} \int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{x^{s-1}e^{-ax}}{1+e^{-x}}\mathrm{d}x=2^{-s}\left(\zeta \left(s,\tfrac{1}{2}a\right)-\zeta\left(s,\tfrac{1}{2}(1+a)\right)\right), subject to \Re a>0, \Re s>0; or \Re a=0, \Im a\neq 0, 0<\Re s<1.
\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\chi(n)}{n^{s}}=k^{-s}\sum_{r=1}^{k}\chi(r)\zeta\left (s,\frac{r}{k}\right), subject to \Re s>1, where \chi(n) is a Dirichlet character \pmod{k} (§LABEL:sec:NT.DIR).
For further sums see ( , pp. 396–397) and ( , pp. 358–360) .
As \beta\to\pm\infty with s fixed, \Re s>1 , \zeta\left(s,\alpha+i\beta\right)\to 0, uniformly with respect to bounded nonnegative values of \alpha.

As a\to\infty in the sector |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\pi-\delta(<\pi) , with s(\neq 1) and \delta fixed, we have the asymptotic expansion \zeta\left(s,a\right)-\frac{a^{1-s}}{s-1}-\frac{1}{2}a^{-s}\sim\sum_{k=1}^{ \infty}\frac{B_{2k}}{(2k)!}{\left(s\right)_{2k-1}}a^{1-s-2k}.

Similarly, as a\to\infty in the sector |\operatorname{ph}a|\leq\frac{1}{2}\pi-\delta(<\frac{1}{2}\pi) , \zeta'\left(-1,a\right)-\frac{1}{12}+\frac{1}{4}a^{2}-\left(\frac{1}{12}-\frac {1}{2}a+\frac{1}{2}a^{2}\right)\ln a\sim-\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{B_{2k+2}}{(2 k+2)(2k+1)2k}a^{-2k}, and \zeta'\left(-2,a\right)-\frac{1}{12}a+\frac{1}{9}a^{3}-\left(\frac{1}{6}a- \frac{1}{2}a^{2}+\frac{1}{3}a^{3}\right)\ln a\sim\sum_{k=1}^{\infty}\frac{2\!B _{2k+2}}{(2k+2)(2k+1)2k(2k-1)}a^{-(2k-1)}.
For the more general case \zeta'\left(-m,a\right) , m=1,2,\dots , see ( ) .
For an exponentially-improved form of (LABEL:eq:ZE.HZE.ASY3) see ( ) .

subsection.title: Dilogarithms

para.sentence: The notation \mathrm{Li}_{2}\left(z\right) was introduced in ( ) for a function discussed in ( ) and called the dilogarithm in ( ) : \mathrm{Li}_{2}\left(z\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{z^{n}}{n^{2}}, subject to |z|\leq 1.
Other notations and names for \mathrm{Li}_{2}\left(z\right) include S_{2}(z) ( ( ) ), Spence function \mathrm{Sp}(z) ( ( ) ), and \mathrm{L}_{2}(z) ( ( ) ).
In the complex plane \mathrm{Li}_{2}\left(z\right) has a branch point at z=1.
The principal branch has a cut along the interval [1,\infty) and agrees with(LABEL:eq:ZE.JON.DI1) when |z|\leq 1 ; see also §LABEL:sec:EF.FN.LOG.
The remainder of the equations in this subsection apply to principal branches.
The cosine series in (LABEL:eq:ZE.JON.DI6) has the elementary sum \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\cos\left(n\theta\right)}{n^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2}}{6}- \frac{\pi\theta}{2}+\frac{\theta^{2}}{4}.
The right-hand side is called Clausen’s integral.
For graphics see Figures LABEL:fig:ZE.GR.dilog and LABEL:fig:ZE.GR.dilog3D, and for further properties see ( ) , ( ) , ( ) , ( ) , and ( ) .

subsection.sentence: Figure 25.12.2: Absolute value of the dilogarithm function \left|\mathrm{Li}_{2}\left(x+iy\right)\right| , -20\leq x\leq 20 , -20\leq y\leq 20 . Principal value. There is a cut along the real axis from 1 to \infty .

para.sentence: For real or complex s and z the polylogarithm \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right) is defined by \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{z^{n}}{n^{s}}.
For each fixed complex s the series defines an analytic function of z for |z|<1.
The series also converges when |z|=1 , provided that \Re s>1.
For other values of z , \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right) is defined by analytic continuation.
The notation \phi\left(z,s\right) was used for \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right) in ( ) for a series treated in ( ) , hence the alternative name Jonquière’s function.
The special case z=1 is the Riemann zeta function: \zeta\left(s\right)=\mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(1\right).

\mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right)=\frac{z}{\Gamma\left(s\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty} \frac{x^{s-1}}{e^{x}-z}\mathrm{d}x, valid when \Re s>0 and \left|\operatorname{ph}\left(1-z\right)\right|<\pi , or \Re s>1 and z=1.

Further properties include \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right)=\Gamma\left(1-s\right)\left(\ln\frac{1}{z}\right )^{s-1}+\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\zeta\left(s-n\right)\frac{(\ln z)^{n}}{n!}, subject to s\neq 1,2,3,\dots, |\ln z|<2\pi, and \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(e^{2\pi ia}\right)+e^{\pi is}\mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(e^{-2 \pi ia}\right)=\frac{(2\pi)^{s}e^{\pi is/2}}{\Gamma\left(s\right)}\zeta\left(1 -s,a\right), valid when \Re s>0 , \Im a>0 or \Re s>1 , \Im a=0.
When s=2 and e^{2\pi ia}=z , (LABEL:eq:ZE.JON.GEN4) becomes (LABEL:eq:ZE.JON.DI4).

The Fermi–Dirac and Bose–Einstein integrals are defined by F_{s}(x)=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(s+1\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{t^{s}}{e^{t-x} +1}\mathrm{d}t, subject to s>-1, , G_{s}(x)=\frac{1}{\Gamma\left(s+1\right)}\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{t^{s}}{e^{t-x} -1}\mathrm{d}t, subject to s>-1, x<0; or s>0, x\leq 0, respectively.
Sometimes the factor 1/\Gamma\left(s+1\right) is omitted. See ( ) and ( ) .
For a uniform asymptotic approximation for F_{s}(x) see ( ) .

The notation F\left(x,s\right) is used for the polylogarithm \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(e^{2\pi ix}\right) with x real: F\left(x,s\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{e^{2\pi inx}}{n^{s}}, where \Re s>1 if x is an integer, \Re s>0 otherwise.
F\left(x,s\right) is periodic in x with period 1, and equals \zeta\left(s\right) when x is an integer.

Also, F\left(x,s\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(1-s\right)}{(2\pi)^{1-s}}\*\left(e^{\pi i( 1-s)/2}\zeta\left(1-s,x\right)+e^{\pi i(s-1)/2}\zeta\left(1-s,1-x\right)\right), subject to 0<x<1, \Re s>1, \zeta\left(1-s,x\right)=\frac{\Gamma\left(s\right)}{(2\pi)^{s}}\left(e^{-\pi is /2}F\left(x,s\right)+e^{\pi is/2}F\left(-x,s\right)\right), subject to 0<x<1, \Re s>0.
For other values of z , \Phi\left(z,s,a\right) is defined by analytic continuation.
This is the notation used in ( , p. 27) .

The Hurwitz zeta function \zeta\left(s,a\right) (§LABEL:sec:ZE.HZE) and the polylogarithm \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right) (§LABEL:sec:ZE.JON.GEN) are special cases: \zeta\left(s,a\right)=\Phi\left(1,s,a\right), subject to \Re s>1, a\neq 0,-1,-2,\dots, \mathrm{Li}_{s}\left(z\right)=z\Phi\left(z,s,1\right), subject to \Re s>1, |z|\leq 1.
With the conditions of (LABEL:eq:ZE.LER.LER2) and m=1,2,3,\dots , \Phi\left(z,s,a\right)=z^{m}\Phi\left(z,s,a+m\right)+\sum_{n=0}^{m-1}\frac{z^{ n}}{(a+n)^{s}}.

\Phi\left(z,s,a\right)=\frac{1}{2}a^{-s}+\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{z^{x}}{(a+x)^{ s}}\mathrm{d}x-2\int_{0}^{\infty}\frac{\sin\left(x\ln z-s\operatorname{arctan} \left(x/a\right)\right)}{(a^{2}+x^{2})^{s/2}(e^{2\pi x}-1)}\mathrm{d}x, subject to \Re s>0 if |z|<1; \Re s>1 if |z|=1,\Re a>0.
For these and further properties see ( , pp. 27–31) .

The notation L\left(s,\chi\right) was introduced by ( ) for the meromorphic continuation of the function defined by the series L\left(s,\chi\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{\chi(n)}{n^{s}}, subject to \Re s>1, where \chi(n) is a Dirichlet character \pmod{k} (§LABEL:sec:NT.DIR).

For the principal character \chi_{1}\pmod{k} , L\left(s,\chi_{1}\right) is analytic everywhere except for a simple pole at s=1 with residue \phi\left(k\right)/k , where \phi\left(k\right) is Euler’s totient function (§LABEL:sec:NT.FU).
If \chi\neq\chi_{1} , then L\left(s,\chi\right) is an entire function of s.
L\left(s,\chi\right)=\prod_{p}\left(1-\frac{\chi(p)}{p^{s}}\right)^{-1}, subject to \Re s>1, with the product taken over all primes p , beginning with p=2.
This implies that L\left(s,\chi\right)\neq 0 if \Re s>1.

Equations (LABEL:eq:ZE.DIR.DIR3) and (LABEL:eq:ZE.DIR.DIR4) hold for all s if \chi\neq\chi_{1} , and for all s ( \neq 1 ) if \chi=\chi_{1} : L\left(s,\chi\right)=k^{-s}\sum_{r=1}^{k-1}\chi(r)\zeta\left(s,\frac{r}{k} \right), , L\left(s,\chi\right)=L\left(s,\chi_{0}\right)\prod_{p\mathbin{|}k}\left(1- \frac{\chi_{0}(p)}{p^{s}}\right), where \chi_{0} is a primitive character (mod d ) for some positive divisor d of k (§LABEL:sec:NT.DIR).

When \chi is a primitive character (mod k ) the L -functions satisfy the functional equation: L\left(1-s,\chi\right)=\frac{k^{s-1}\Gamma\left(s\right)}{(2\pi)^{s}}\*{\left( e^{-\pi is/2}+\chi(-1)e^{\pi is/2}\right)}\*G(\chi)L\left(s,\overline{\chi} \right), where \overline{\chi} is the complex conjugate of \chi , and G(\chi)=\sum_{r=1}^{k}\chi(r)e^{2\pi ir/k}.

Since L\left(s,\chi\right)\neq 0 if \Re s>1 , (LABEL:eq:ZE.DIR.DIR5) shows that for a primitive character \chi the only zeros of L\left(s,\chi\right) for \Re s<0 (the so-called trivial zeros) are as follows: L\left(-2n,\chi\right)=0\text{ if }\chi(-1)=1, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots, L\left(-2n-1,\chi\right)=0\text{ if }\chi(-1)=-1, subject to n=0,1,2,\dots.
There are also infinitely many zeros in the critical strip 0\leq\Re s\leq 1 , located symmetrically about the critical line \Re s=\frac{1}{2} , but not necessarily symmetrically about the realaxis.
L\left(1,\chi\right)\neq 0\text{ if }\chi\neq\chi_{1}, where \chi_{1} is the principal character \pmod{k}.
This result plays an important role in the proof of Dirichlet’s theorem on primes in arithmetic progressions (§LABEL:sec:NT.ASY).

In studying the distribution of primes p\leq x , ( ) introduced a function \psi\left(x\right) (not to be confused with the digamma function used elsewhere in this chapter), given by \psi\left(x\right)=\sum_{m=1}^{\infty}\sum_{p^{m}\leq x}\ln p, which is related to the Riemann zeta function by \psi\left(x\right)=x-\frac{\zeta'\left(0\right)}{\zeta\left(0\right)}-\sum_{ \rho}\frac{x^{\rho}}{\rho}+o\left(1\right), subject to x\to\infty, where the sum is taken over the nontrivial zeros \rho of \zeta\left(s\right).
The prime number theorem (LABEL:eq:NT.FU.PNT) is equivalent to the statement \psi\left(x\right)=x+o\left(x\right), subject to x\to\infty.
The Riemann hypothesis is equivalent to the statement \psi\left(x\right)=x+O\left(x^{\frac{1}{2}+\epsilon}\right), subject to x\to\infty, for every \epsilon>0.
Euler sums have the form H\left(s\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{h(n)}{n^{s}}, where h(n) is given by (LABEL:eq:ZE.HZE.EI5new).

For integer s ( \geq 2 ), H\left(s\right) can be evaluated in terms of the zeta function: H\left(2\right)=2\zeta\left(3\right), H\left(3\right)=\tfrac{5}{4}\zeta\left(4\right), H\left(a\right)=\frac{a+2}{2}\zeta\left(a+1\right)-\frac{1}{2}\sum_{r=1}^{a-2} \zeta\left(r+1\right)\zeta\left(a-r\right), subject to a=2,3,4,\dots.

H\left(s\right) is the special case H\left(s,1\right) of the function H\left(s,z\right)=\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n^{s}}\sum_{m=1}^{n}\frac{1}{m^{ z}}, subject to \Re(s+z)>1, which satisfies the reciprocity law H\left(s,z\right)+H\left(z,s\right)=\zeta\left(s\right)\zeta\left(z\right)+ \zeta\left(s+z\right), when both H\left(s,z\right) and H\left(z,s\right) are finite.

Analogies exist between the distribution of the zeros of \zeta\left(s\right) on the critical line and of semiclassical quantum eigenvalues.
This relates to a suggestion of Hilbert and Pólya that the zeros are eigenvalues of some operator, and the Riemann hypothesis is true if that operator is Hermitian.

The zeta function arises in the calculation of the partition function of ideal quantum gases (both Bose–Einstein and Fermi–Dirac cases), and it determines the critical gas temperature and density for the Bose–Einstein condensation phase transition in a dilute gas ( ( ) ).

Quantum field theory often encounters formally divergent sums that need to be evaluated by a process of regularization: for example, the energy of the electromagnetic vacuum in a confined space (Casimir–Polder effect).
It has been found possible to perform such regularizations by equating the divergent sums to zeta functions and associated functions ( ( ) ).

Calculations to date (2008) have found no nontrivial zeros off the critical line.
